Subject: Re: CPPN References??
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=345995616; y=m6Zl4RzvVEkA1dcs9cXjeVAKl8DlCwK3sSdFssOzjC-zaQHhIlkR

You've captured the basic idea.  Let me expand on it a bit.

One of the cur=
rently leading problems in computational chemistry or
molecular modeling is=
 coming up with a method to predict the affinity
of a small molecule for th=
e binding site of a protein.  In the case
where you have a model of the bin=
ding site (typically from a crystal
structure), there are tools that will a=
ccurately position a small
molecule into the binding site, however, there i=
s not a good scoring
function that will give you an estimate of the activit=
y that small
molecule will have against the protein.  It seems counter-intu=
itive -
we can accurately place the molecule in the right 3D conformation i=
nto
the 3D binding site, but we can't really tell you how active it will
be=
.  In other cases you do not have a model of the protein.  In both
cases yo=
u may have a number of compounds for which the activity is known.

For smal=
l molecules to bind to a protein/enzyme, they will be required
to make a nu=
mber of interactions with that protein.  This implies that
they must be the=
 correct shape, obviously, but they must also place
the correct types of at=
oms/groups in the right place to make those
interactions.  Often, the bulk =
of the compound is used to place things
into the right locations in order t=
o get an interaction - to get the
right shape.

Given the CPPN's ability to=
 capture spatial relationships, I'm
wondering if it could be used as an eva=
luator for the strength of an
interaction of this sort.  The spatial relati=
onships of interest may
stem from the small molecules themselves, the prote=
in binding site, or
a combination of the two.  All of this is going on in a=
 3D space
defined by the protein binding site.

Obviously I need to think a=
bout this further, but there very well may
be something useful here that ha=
sn't yet been tried.  






--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley"=
 <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Kirk, I think that's a very interesting potentia=
l application area.  
> Let me make sure I'm understanding how it would wor=
k.  You are saying
> that you might capture the shape of a protein binding =
region (or some
> other important region) with a CPPN and then use that CPP=
N-encoded
> model to test other chemical compounds?  
> 
> But if you alrea=
dy have a model of the intended shape, what additional
> capability would t=
he CPPN provide other than encoding the 3D model
> that you already have?  =
Or do you mean you might try creating new
> shapes with the CPPN that you h=
aven't thought of and see how they
> react with known compounds?  There are=
 probably other ways it could go
> as well, but I'm curious from the point =
of view of computational
> chemistry where the most exciting opportunity wo=
uld be.  
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "newtwist2000" <rkdeli=
sle@> wrote:
> >
> > I may be over-interpreting the CPPN process, but it st=
imulated a few
> > ideas.  I work in the field of Computational Chemistry a=
nd my in my
> > day to day operations I deal with drug-like chemical compou=
nds.  The
> > 3D shape of a chemical is a principle determining factor of i=
ts
> > activity.  On top of 3D shape, you have different functional groups
=
> > that impart different properties.  For example, let's say the shape is
=
> > just right to bind to a particular enzyme (and prevent it from running
=
> > amok) but you need an oxygen atom at a particular location, or a
> > ni=
trogen, or any atom with a hydrogen attached, etc.
> > 
> > There are two w=
ays to get to this type of information.  First is
> > having a large collec=
tion of chemicals with a known endpoint.  For
> > this I usually apply the =
standard pattern recognition tools.  Another
> > more difficult approach is=
 when you don't have much data for
> > chemicals, but you know the 3D struc=
ture of the enzyme and where you
> > want your chemical to bind.  I'm wonde=
ring if there is an application
> > for CPPNs here.  Can the CPPN capture t=
he shape of the site along with
> > the essential properties based on the p=
rotein itself and then be used
> > to assess different chemical compounds t=
hat have not yet been tested -
> > try to predict their activities.
> > 
> =
> Any thoughts??
> > 
> > -Kirk
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.=
com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Kirk, what is your id=
ea for applying CPPNs to pattern
recognition?  I
> > > am not sure I follow=
ed exactly how the CPPN would be connected
to the
> > > neural network?
> >=
 > 
> > > As Peter mentioned, we have used the idea of CPPNs to represent
>=
 > > connectivity patterns rather than the spatial patterns you saw
in the
=
> > > CPPN paper.  These connectivity patterns can then be interpreted of
>=
 > > neural network connectivity patterns, which means you can evolve
> > >=
 neural networks with regularities in their connectivities. 
There are
> > =
> currently four papers on this approach to evolving ANNs with CPPNs,
> > >=
 which is called HyperNEAT.  Those papers are available from my
> homepage
=
> > > 
> > > http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/
> > > 
> > > or from EPlex pu=
blications:
> > > 
> > > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications.html
> > > 
>=
 > > The particular papers are:
> > > 
> > > -A Novel Generative Encoding f=
or Exploiting Neural Network
Sensor and 
> > > Output Geometry
> > > 
> > >=
 -Generating Large-Scale Neural Networks Through Discovering
Geometric
> > =
> Regularities 
> > > 
> > > -A Case Study on the Critical Role of Geometri=
c Regularity in
Machine
> > > Learning
> > > 
> > > -Generative Encoding fo=
r Multiagent Learning 
> > > 
> > > A longer journal paper on HyperNEAT is =
also forthcoming in
Artificial
> > > Life journal.
> > > 
> > > By the way,=
 you can also interactively evolve your own CPPNs images
> > > online at ht=
tp://picbreeder.org
> > > 
> > > Because spatial patterns and connectivity =
patterns can represent
just
> > > about anything, there are other potential=
 applications of CPPNs
beyond
> > > representing ANNs, but currently there =
is no publication of such an
> > > application that I know of.  But it woul=
d be interesting to see more
> > > work in that direction.
> > > 
> > > ken=
 
> > > 
> > > 
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <peta=
r_chervenski@>
> > > wrote:
> > > >
> > > > HyperNEAT uses CPPNs to build t=
he neural network phenotypes (and 
> > > > evolves CPPNs). I see this as an=
 extension. There are about 3 or
> more 
> > > > papers on HyperNEAT. It sh=
ould be interesting to you, though it is
> > just 
> > > > one of all possi=
ble applications. 
> > > > 
> > > > Peter
> > > > 
> > > > --- In neat@yaho=
ogroups.com, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > I've ju=
st read through the paper Compositional Pattern Producing
> > > > > Network=
s: A Novel Abstraction of Development - very interesting
> > stuff.
> > > >=
 >  
> > > > > Are there additional papers that extend on this?  Currently
=
> what I'm
> > > > > seeing is based on visual representations, but are the=
re papers
> > where
> > > > > this has been extended to pattern recognition=
 or other
fields?  My
> > > > > thought is that if a CPPN can capture impor=
tant spatial
> details that
> > > > > can then be evaluated by a standard N=
N, can the two improve on
> > pattern
> > > > > recognition tasks that have=
 a relative spatial component -
> > > > > topological, geometric, higher di=
mensions...
> > > > > 
> > > > > -Kirk
